articles.headline: Jury Finds Blagojevich Guilty of Corruption
articles.snippet: A jury in Chicago convicted the former governor of Illinois, Rod R. Blagojevich, of nearly all the corruption charges against him.
articles.abstract: A jury in Chicago convicted the former governor of Illinois, Rod R. Blagojevich, of nearly all the corruption charges against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A jury on Monday convicted Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, of a broad pattern of corruption, including charges that he tried to personally benefit from his role in selecting a replacement for President Obama in the United States Senate.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Emma G. Fitzsimmons

articles.headline: Afghans Build Security, and Hope to Avoid Infiltrators
articles.snippet: Officials concede that with more than 8,000 army and police recruits enlisting each month, the task of screening is monumental.
articles.abstract: Officials concede that with more than 8,000 army and police recruits enlisting each month, the task of screening is monumental.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For someone who had once joined an insurgent group, and whose family was tied to a top Taliban commander, Akmal had a strikingly easy path into the Afghan National Army.

articles.headline: In the Teamsters, a Candidate Tries to Break the Mold
articles.snippet: Sandy Pope, the first woman to run for the presidency of the very macho union, faces an uphill battle as she tries to unseat James P. Hoffa.
articles.abstract: Sandy Pope, the first woman to run for the presidency of the very macho union, faces an uphill battle as she tries to unseat James P. Hoffa.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sandy Pope acknowledges straightaway that she faces an uphill battle — she is the first woman to run for the presidency of the very macho Teamsters union, and she is running against a three-term incumbent, James P. Hoffa, who has the most famous last name in American labor.

articles.headline: Microsoft Takes to Cloud to Ward Off Competition
articles.snippet: Google’s Web alternatives to Microsoft Office are pulling business away from the company’s biggest money maker.
articles.abstract: Google’s Web alternatives to Microsoft Office are pulling business away from the company’s biggest money maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: People like Tom Conophy are stirring anxiety — and action — in Microsoft’s executive offices these days.

articles.headline: New Drugs Fight Prostate Cancer, but at High Cost
articles.snippet: The drugs, mainly for men with late-stage prostate cancer, can extend lives for additional months, but some cost more than $90,000 for a course of treatment.
articles.abstract: The drugs, mainly for men with late-stage prostate cancer, can extend lives for additional months, but some cost more than $90,000 for a course of treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of new drugs is promising to prolong the lives and relieve the symptoms of men with advanced prostate cancer, but could also add billions of dollars to the nation’s medical bills.

articles.headline: A Congressman’s Pet Project; a Railroad’s Boon
articles.snippet: Representative John L. Mica has been the 61-mile SunRail line’s biggest supporter since he first proposed it in 1992.
articles.abstract: Representative John L. Mica has been the 61-mile SunRail line’s biggest supporter since he first proposed it in 1992.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Here in sun-parched Central Florida, workers are ready to break ground this summer for a 61-mile commuter rail project that the federal government ranks as one of the least cost-effective mass transit efforts in the nation.

articles.headline: Rescue Measures for Greece Advance as French Offer to Ease Debt
articles.snippet: Under the plan, French banks would give Athens more time to pay back loans as they come due over the next three years.
articles.abstract: Under the plan, French banks would give Athens more time to pay back loans as they come due over the next three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: European leaders inched closer Monday to an agreement that could avoid a potentially catastrophic default by Greece on billions of dollars in debt, as France proposed a plan that could serve as a model for other European lenders to the teetering nation, where a general strike and widespread demonstrations were planned Tuesday ahead of a crucial austerity vote.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Matthew Saltmarsh
